metadata.case_name: State of Assam v. Respondents (Owners of plot at Bharalumukh, Gauhati)

facts.text: Respondents are owners of a plot of land at Bharalumukh, Gauhati, on which stands a residential building.

In 1943, Government of India requisitioned the land and building under rule 75-A of the Defence of India Rules, 1939, for use of defence forces. Land and building continued in possession of Government of India since requisition.

On February 9, 1949, Collector of Kamrup passed order for acquisition of land and building under s.4 of Assam Land Requisition and Acquisition Act, 1948, while requisition by Government of India was subsisting.
On August 4, 1949, Collector requisitioned the land under s.3 of Assam Act 1948, effective from February 7, 1949.
Collector assessed compensation payable to respondents under s.7 of the Act.
Respondents applied for reference to Civil Court under s.8 of the Act and challenged authority of Collector to acquire the land.
Subordinate Judge, Gauhati held no valid acquisition but assessed compensation if acquisition valid.
Assam High Court confirmed order holding acquisition invalid, in judgment dated February 10, 1958 in Appeals from Original Decrees Nos. 10 to 21 of 1953.
State of Assam filed appeals to Supreme Court with certificate granted by High Court.

legal_issues.text: Validity of acquisition proceedings commenced by Collector under s.4 of Assam Land Requisition and Acquisition Act, 1948, where land was previously requisitioned under rule 75-A of Defence of India Rules, 1939, not under s.3 of the Act.
Whether order of acquisition saved by s.11 of the Act notwithstanding illegality.

petitioner_arguments.text: Notwithstanding the illegality in the acquisition, the order of acquisition was saved by s.11 of the Assam Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 11, Assam Land Requisition and Acquisition Act, 1948

respondent_arguments.text: Challenged the authority of the Collector to acquire the land in the manner done, as acquisition under s.4 requires prior requisition under s.3.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 3 and 4, Assam Land Requisition and Acquisition Act, 1948

court_reasoning.text: Power to acquire under s.4(1) may be exercised only where land has been requisitioned under s.3 and not otherwise.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Acquisition order made first on Feb 9, 1949 under s.4; later requisition order on Aug 4, 1949 under s.3 with backdate cannot validate illegal acquisition.

court_reasoning.text: Previous requisition under Defence of India Rules does not confer authority on Provincial Government to acquire under s.4 of Assam Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Requisition under rule 75-A was by Government of India, not under s.3 of Assam Act.

court_reasoning.text: s.11 does not save the order as it was not made in exercise of power conferred by the Act, lacking effective prior requisition under s.3.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order under s.4 defective ab initio.

holdings.text: Acquisition proceedings under s.4 invalid as land not requisitioned under s.3 of the Act.
s.11 does not bar challenge to validity of acquisition order.

statutes_cited.name: Assam Land (Requisition and Acquisition) Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs requisition and acquisition; s.4 requires prior s.3 requisition for valid acquisition; s.11 does not save invalid orders.

statutes_cited.name: Defence of India Rules, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Prior requisition under this rule by Government of India does not enable acquisition under Assam Act s.4.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals filed by State of Assam, upholding Assam High Court judgment that acquisition of respondents' land under s.4 of Assam Land Requisition and Acquisition Act, 1948 was invalid.
outcome.relief_granted: Acquisition declared invalid; no acquisition vests land in government.

key_quotes.text: The power to acquire land under s. 4 may, it is plain from a bare perusal of sub-s. (1), be exercised where the land has been requisitioned under s. 3 and not otherwise.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on statutory requirement for valid acquisition.

key_quotes.text: By this expedient, an illegal order of acquisition could not be validated.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects backdated requisition to cure defect.

key_quotes.text: Save as otherwise expressly provided in this Act, no decision or order made in exercise of any power conferred by or under this Act shall be called in question in any Court.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.11 but holds it inapplicable.
